episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser. This note concerns the Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction case, docket number 2022-00007, arising under Keith Graser’s Workers’ Compensation matter, with the Estate of Keith Graser as the client.

In December 2023, Jessica Wiedersatz, a paralegal with U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, sent two subpoena duces tecum documents to Abbie G. Lewis at ky.gov in connection with the Graser v. Coupe Construction case. The emails indicated that the subpoenas were to be reviewed and signed by Judge Rice-Smith (Judge Rice-Smith’s assistant, Abbie Lewis), so that the requested additional information could be obtained in the claim. Jessica noted that she had copied Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office on the communication. The email was dated December 27, 2023, at 2:41 PM, and it carried the subject Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007. Jessica attached the two subpoenas, and she reminded Abbie that two subpoena duces tecums were attached for review and sign-off. The message also included a confidentiality disclaimer and a caution regarding PDF attachments that may contain links to malicious sites.

The communications show that Jessica’s outreach was part of a broader sequence. In the same chain, on December 27, 2023, Jessica’s message to Abbie included that she had copied Sarena Tuttle and had provided Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office with the information to keep them informed. The signature block for Jessica included her role as Paralegal at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates and her contact details: 100 Mallard Creek Road, Suite 110, Louisville, KY 40207; phone 502-736-3600; fax 502-736-3606; website www.umakylaw.com; and a note stating the firm has provided Workers’ Compensation defense throughout Kentucky and Indiana since 2002.

Subsequently, on January 4, 2024 at 11:58 AM, Jessica forwarded the prior thread to Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims. In that forwarding, she explained that the attachments and the prior communications had been sent to Judge Rice-Smith’s assistant, Abbie, on 12/27/24. She then noted that Judge Kimberly O’Bryan had been assigned to the claim and that she wanted to send the attached subpoenas to Lisa for Judge O’Bryan’s review and signature. Jessica stated that she had copied Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office on the email so they would be aware of the communication, and she requested Lisa’s assistance. The message carried the same subject line as before and included the standard courtesy to contact her office if any further information was needed. The email also contained the confidentiality notice that appears in the correspondence.

Lisa C. Chaffin responded on January 9, 2024, at 2:56 PM. In her reply, she asked Jessica to resubmit the subpoenas with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s name in place of Monica Rice Smith’s. She thanked Jessica for the update and identified her role as the Paralegal to Kimberly O’Bryan, Administrative Law Judge, with the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims. The message included a confidential information disclaimer.

Later that same day, January 9, 2024, at 20:01:16 +0000, Jessica replied that she had mistakenly believed she had sent the updated subpoenas previously. She apologized to Lisa and attached the updated subpoenas, this time with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s name included. She stated, “My apologies, Lisa. I could have sworn I sent the updated subpoenas to you, but apparently I didn't! Please find them attached.” The email again cited the subject Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007 and included the confidential information disclaimer from the recipient’s message thread.

Across these exchanges, the subject remained consistent: Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007, in which the Estate of Keith Graser seeks subpoenas duces tecums to obtain additional information in the claim, with Judge O’Bryan (Kimberly O’Bryan) now assigned to the matter, and updates to substitute her name for Monica Rice Smith’s on the subpoenas.

Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, who serves as Paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, wrote to Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, cc’ing Sarena Tuttle. Earlier correspondence shows that on January 4, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz forwarded an email to Lisa Chaffin, with Abbie G. Lewis (Judge Rice-Smith’s assistant) CC’d, explaining that she had sent the attached material to Abbie on 12/27/24 and that Judge O’Bryan has now been assigned to the claim. The purpose of the attached materials was to obtain the attached subpoenas for review and signature by Judge O’Bryan, and Wiedersatz noted that she had also copied Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office so they would be aware of the communication.

The chain traces further back to December 27, 2023, when Jessica Wiedersatz, as a paralegal for U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, sent an email to AbbieG.Lewis@ky.gov with the subject “Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007.” In that message, she stated that two subpoena duces tecums were attached and requested Judge Rice-Smith to review and sign them so that additional information could be obtained in the claim. Wiedersatz copied Sarena Tuttle and noted that Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office was copied on the email as well. The January 4, 2024 email from Wiedersatz included a note referencing the December 27, 2023 communication to Abbie and indicated that the attached subpoenas were to be reviewed and signed by Judge Rice-Smith so that additional information could be obtained in the case. episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser.

The matter described is Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction (2022-00007). Over the course of several communications in January 2024, the parties discussed obtaining signed subpoenas and scheduling depositions in the case, with particular attention to having documents from PNC and Discover produced before deposition.

The sequence begins with an email from Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, on January 19, 2024. She informed Jessica Wiedersatz that she had the judge’s permission to sign subpoenas on the judge’s behalf and to issue them, but she noted that she and her office were snowed in and working from home, with no ability to print or scan and return documents. She said she would figure out a solution and work on the matter that day and would keep Jessica posted. In her signature block, Chaffin identified herself as paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan.

Earlier, on January 18, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz, a paralegal at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, wrote that they had not yet received signed subpoenas back and were concerned there might not be enough time to forward the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by the deposition date of January 24, 2024. Jessica attached updated subpoenas with a new deposition date of February 9, 2024 and explained that this change was intended to provide more time to obtain Judge O’Bryan’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. She also noted that she would reschedule Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition to ensure the parties would have the documents from PNC and Discover before taking the deposition. In this email, she cc’d Sarena Tuttle to keep the other side informed and indicated she would send another email regarding the rescheduling.

The thread shows a longer back-and-forth earlier in January. On January 17, 2024, Chaffin replied that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office the next day to sign. Earlier that same day, Jessica had asked for an update on whether Judge O’Bryan had signed the subpoenas they had sent, expressing appreciation for any information she could provide.

On January 9, 2024, there was a push to update the subpoenas with the correct judge’s name. Jessica’s message at 3:01 PM acknowledged an earlier delay in sending the updated subpoenas and included the updated attachments. Lisa replied at 4:17 PM, confirming that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign. Earlier that day, at 2:56 PM, Lisa had requested that Jessica replace Monica Rice Smith’s name with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s on the subpoenas. Jessica confirmed the update with her 3:01 PM message, and the exchange included cautionary notes about PDF attachments potentially containing links to malicious sites.

A prior exchange from January 9, 2024 also shows Jessica’s earlier outreach requesting status updates on the signing of the subpoenas, and Lisa’s acknowledgment that she would ensure Judge O’Bryan would sign. This sequence followed an earlier message on January 9, 2024 at 9:27 AM from Jessica requesting information on the status of Judge O’Bryan’s signing.

The thread’s earlier portion shows correspondence beginning with Jessica’s message on January 4, 2024. In that communication, she referenced that they had sent the attached subpoenas and the information below to Judge Rice-Smith’s assistant, Abbie, on December 27, 2024 (a date that appears to be a typographical note in the record). Jessica stated that Judge O’Bryan had been assigned to the claim and that she wanted Abbie to review and sign the subpoenas, and she noted that she had copied Mr. Graser’s attorneys on the communication.

That December 27, 2023 note is followed by the January 4, 2024 message from Jessica to Lisa, reiterating that the subpoenas had been sent to Abbie for Judge Rice-Smith’s review and signature, with Abbie and Mr. Graser’s attorneys copied for awareness.

In addition to the above, the record shows that the subpoenas were issued in the Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction matter, with the subpoenas directed to PNC and Discover, and that the deposition dates on initial submissions were set for January 24, 2024, with a plan to realign to later dates as needed to accommodate the production of documents.

Overall, the communications reflect an effort to obtain sign-off on subpoenas from the Administrative Law Judge (initially Judge Rice-Smith, later replaced by Judge Kimberly O’Bryan), to adjust the subpoenas to reflect the correct judge’s name, and to reschedule depositions to allow time for document production from PNC and Discover. The parties also noted practical challenges, including weather-related barriers to processing documents, which led to the decision to set a new deposition date of February 9, 2024, on the updated subpoenas, and to consider rescheduling the 1/30/24 deposition in light of document availability.

In sum, these notes chronicle the lead-up to and modification of subpoenas in the Estate of Keith Graser’s case against Coupe Construction, detailing judge sign-offs, changes of judge name, deposition scheduling shifts from late January toward early February, and the logistical issues encountered in issuing and returning signed subpoenas.

episodes.natural_language:
This note relates to the Estate of Keith Graser in the Workers’ Compensation case Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction (2022-00007). The communications are between the Estate’s counsel and state agency personnel responsible for issuing subpoenas, with the goal of obtaining subpoenas duces tecum and securing signatures from Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, so that documents from PNC and Discover could be produced before deposition dates.

The sequence begins with December 27, 2023, when Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates emailed Abbie G. Lewis at ky.gov, attaching two subpoena duces tecums and requesting Judge Rice-Smith to review them. The email, sent to Abbie with Sarena Tuttle copied, was titled Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007. In the body, Jessica wrote that the two subpoenas were attached for Judge Rice-Smith’s review.

By January 4, 2024, Jessica followed up, noting that Abbie Rice-Smith’s assistant had previously received the attached subpoenas on 12/27/24 (a date that appears to be a typographical error in the record). She explained that Judge O’Bryan had been assigned to the claim and indicated she would send the attached subpoenas to Lisa Chaffin for the judge’s review and signature, copying Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office so they would be aware of the communication.

On January 9, 2024, Lisa Chaffin replied that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign. Earlier that same day, in her reply, Lisa asked Jessica to resubmit the subpoenas with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s name replacing Monica Rice Smith’s. Jessica responded shortly after, apologizing for the confusion and attaching the updated subpoenas. Lisa followed with another note at 2:56 PM requesting the substitution, and at 4:17 PM she confirmed that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign the updated subpoenas.

In the subsequent days, Jessica checked in regarding the signing. On January 17, 2024, she asked Lisa for an update on whether Judge O’Bryan had signed the subpoenas. Lisa replied that the judge would be back in the office the next day to sign. Jessica acknowledged and asked for the status again, while Lisa confirmed the plan to obtain the judge’s signature.

By January 18, 2024, Jessica explained that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and expressed concern about timing. She attached updated subpoenas with a new deposition date of February 9, 2024, in hopes of giving more time to obtain Judge O’Bryan’s signatures and to issue the requests to PNC and Discover. Jessica noted that they would like to have documents from PNC and Discover prior to taking Keith Graser’s deposition and mentioned rescheduling Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition. She told Sarena Tuttle that she would send another email regarding the rescheduling and thanked Jessica for the assistance. The note also included Jessica’s professional contact information and the firm’s branding.

Finally, on January 22, 2024, Lisa Chaffin sent a follow-up email with the subject line “Re: Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007,” stating that the subpoenas were signed and attached. The message closed with the standard confidentiality footer used by the Office of Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims.

Throughout these exchanges, the primary issues were: replacing the earlier requester names on the subpoenas to reflect Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, obtaining the judge’s signatures, coordinating with Abbie Rice-Smith’s office and later Abbie Lewis’s involvement, accommodating rescheduling needs for deposition dates (notably moving from 1/24/24 to 2/9/24 for the deposition date on the subpoenas), and ensuring documents from PNC and Discover would be in hand before Keith Graser’s deposition (initially set for 1/30/24). The communications also show ongoing coordination with Sarena Tuttle of Whaley Law Firm and the involvement of Mr. Graser’s attorneys as recipients on the correspondences.

Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020
Client: Estate of Keith Graser

In the matter concerning the deposition of Nancy Graser in the Estate of Keith Graser (case WC-12-07-2020), communications regarding scheduling were exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm and Uma Sells Mayer & Associates. The Whaley firm represented the Estate of Keith Graser, and the deposition issue centered on Ms. Graser in connection with the Keith Graser matter.

On January 18, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates emailed Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm, proposing to reschedule Ms. Graser’s Zoom deposition, which was originally set for January 30, 2024, to a date after February 9, 2024. The aim was to allow time to obtain documentation from PNC and Discover prior to the deposition. Jessica asked whether any of the following dates could work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon: February 13; February 14 (afternoon); February 15 (afternoon); February 19; and February 20 (afternoon). The message included Jessica’s contact details and stated that Uma Sells Mayer & Associates provides Workers’ Compensation defense in Kentucky and Indiana since 2002. Jessica’s firm address was listed as 100 Mallard Creek Road, Suite 110, Louisville, KY 40207, with phone (502) 736-3600 and fax (502) 736-3606.

Sarena Tuttle replied on January 19, 2024 (time listed as 10:47?AM in the record), explaining that while she understood the desire to reschedule again, she would need to confer with Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon regarding any possible objections to a second rescheduling. She indicated she would update Jessica as soon as possible. Sarena’s signature identified her as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, located at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, with direct dial (502) 357-9971 and office line (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email address Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. The signature also noted to “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

A follow-up exchange occurred on January 22, 2024. In that message, also from Sarena Tuttle to Jessica Wiedersatz (time listed as 10:29:37 -0500 in the header), Sarena stated that the office had received the executed SDTs back that morning and that they should hold off on rescheduling for the time being. She explained that it can take some time to receive a proper response from such companies and that their office would want to review any and all documents received prior to the deposition of Mrs. Graser. She invited Jessica and her office to contact them directly if they had any questions in further detail. This January 22 email was CC’d to Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon of The Whaley Law Firm. The Whaley firm’s address, contact details, and Sarena’s updated email (noted in her signature as the new address) were included in the correspondence.

In sum, the parties discussed delaying Ms. Graser’s deposition to obtain necessary documents from third-party lenders, with a plan to confirm objection-based rescheduling, and, as of January 22, 2024, the Wranglers held off on rescheduling while awaiting the SDTs’ responses and a review of incoming documents. The communications also documented the involved firms’ contact details and the fact that the correspondence included CCs to Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate of Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction, case 2022-00007, the matter in early 2024 involved obtaining discovery from Discover Bank and PNC. The attorney team, led by Jessica Wiedersatz, planned to issue subpoenas and deposition notices not to hold live depositions, but to secure the requested information from Discover and PNC.

On January 4, 2024, Jessica emailed Lisa C. Chaffin to note that updated subpoenas needed to be reviewed for Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s signatures, since Judge O’Bryan had been assigned to the claim. She explained that they had previously sent the attached materials to Judge Rice-Smith’s assistant, Abbie, on December 27, 2024 (a detail reflected in the thread), and she requested review and signatures. Jessica also copied Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office on that message.

On January 9, 2024, Lisa responded that the subpoenas should be resubmitted with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s name in place of Monica Rice Smith’s, and Jessica apologized for not sending the updated subpoenas earlier, attaching them for the judge’s review. Later that same day, at 3:01 PM, Jessica again apologized for the oversight and confirmed that the updated subpoenas were attached.

By 4:17 PM on January 9, 2024, Lisa indicated that there was no problem and that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign the subpoenas, with confidentiality notices included in the correspondence.

On January 17, 2024, Jessica checked in on the status of Judge O’Bryan signing the subpoenas. Lisa replied at 10:31 AM that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office the next day to sign. Earlier, at 9:27 AM, Jessica had again inquired about the signing status.

On January 18, 2024, Jessica noted that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and expressed concern that there would not be enough time to issue the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by the 1/24/24 deposition date shown on the subpoenas. In response, she attached updated subpoenas with a deposition date of 2/9/24 and stated that this would give more time to obtain O’Bryan’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. She informed Sarena that she was CC’ing her to keep her abreast of communications with the ALJ’s office and that she would send another email about rescheduling Ms. Graser’s 1/30/24 deposition so that documents from PNC and Discover could be reviewed prior to the deposition.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa sent an email with attached signed subpoenas and asked Jessica to let her know if there were any questions or concerns. Jessica replied the same day, attaching copies of the letters, deposition notices, and subpoenas that were being sent to Discover and PNC. She reiterated that the depositions themselves were not planned, and clarified that the goal was simply to obtain the requested information from Discover and PNC. The email also included the notes that the deposition date previously referenced in the subpoenas was 1/24/24, and that the flow of documents was intended to precede any deposition.

Throughout this sequence, several confidentiality notices and standard cautions about email content and attachments appeared in the communications, reflecting the sensitive nature of the workers’ compensation proceeding.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020, Estate of Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction, case number 2022-00007, involves the Whaley Law Firm on behalf of the Estate of Keith Graser and opposing counsel at Umaki Law, with communications among Sarena M. Tuttle, Jessica Wiedersatz, and Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet’s Department of Workers’ Claims.

On Monday, January 22, 2024, Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, acknowledged receipt of the prior materials. In her email, she provided her contact information and noted a new email address. Earlier that day, Jessica Wiedersatz at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates informed Sarena that attached to her message were copies of letters, deposition notices, and subpoenas being sent to Discover and PNC. Jessica explained that the deposits would not be held; rather, the purpose was to obtain the requested information from Discover and PNC.

In a prior thread, Lisa C. Chaffin, paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan in the Education & Labor Cabinet’s Department of Workers’ Claims, had sent a message indicating that the subpoenas were signed and attached, asking for whether any questions or concerns remained. This was followed by a series of communications starting January 18 and continuing into January 22, 2024, concerning the timing and signatures for the subpoenas.

On January 18, 2024, Jessica noted that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and were concerned there would not be enough time to deliver the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by the deposition date of January 24, 2024, as specified on the subpoenas. In light of this, updated subpoenas with a new deposition date of February 9, 2024 were prepared in hopes of allowing time to obtain the Administrative Law Judge’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. Jessica also informed Sarena that she would send a separate update regarding rescheduling Keith Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition so that they could obtain the documents from PNC and Discover prior to taking the deposition. Jessica included a cc to Sarena to keep her apprised of communications with the ALJ’s office.

Earlier in the thread, on January 17, 2024, Lisa had indicated that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office the next day to sign. Jessica followed up on January 17, 2024, asking for the status of the judge’s signature. Lisa had previously replied on January 9, 2024, that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign the subpoenas. In that January 9 exchange, Jessica apologized for not sending the updated subpoenas and attached them. Lisa had earlier requested that the subpoenas be resubmitted with Judge Kimberly O’Bryan’s name in place of Monica Rice Smith’s.

The chain also includes standard confidentiality notices typical of communications from the Education & Labor Cabinet and the involved law firms. Overall, by January 22, 2024, the parties were coordinating to obtain signed subpoenas and signatures from Judge O’Bryan, reschedule the Graser deposition initially set for January 30, 2024, and extend the subpoena response timeline to February 9, 2024 to ensure Discover and PNC could be served and that the associated documents could be obtained before Keith Graser’s deposition.

In the period surrounding January 2024, communications were exchanged between The Whaley Law Firm and U’Sellis Mayer & Associates regarding the deposition of Nancy Graser in the Keith Graser matter. On Monday, January 22, 2024, at 11:37:48 -0500, Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers' Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm (address: 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct line 502-357-9971; office line 502-583-4022 ext 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com; note: new email address), sent a message to Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates (address: 100 Mallard Creek Road, Suite 110, Louisville, KY 40207; phone 502-736-3600; fax 502-736-3606) with CCs to Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon. The purpose of the note was simply to convey thanks.

In a response, Jessica Wiedersatz stated: “Thanks, Sarena. Attached please find a notice cancelling Ms. Graser’s 1/30/24 deposition.” This indicated that a notice cancelling the deposition had been attached to her reply.

Earlier that same day, at 10:30 AM, Sarena had written to Jessica: “Good morning Jessica, We see that your office received the executed SDTs back this morning. Let's hold off on rescheduling for the time being. As we are sure you're aware it can take some time to receive a proper response from such companies and our office will want to review any and all documents received prior to the deposition of Mrs. Graser. If you or your office has any questions, please do not hesitate to contact us directly to discuss them in further detail.” This conveyed that the parties intended to review any documents received before scheduling further deposition steps.

Earlier still, on Friday, January 19, 2024, at 10:47 AM, Sarena wrote: “Good morning Jessica, While I understand the desire to reschedule this deposition again, I will need to confer with Mr. Whaley & Mr. Koon for any possible objections they may have to a second rescheduling. I will update you as soon as possible.” This noted the need to confer with the firm’s principals before any additional rescheduling.

And on Thursday, January 18, 2024, at 4:13 PM, Jessica had written: “Hi, Sarena – As you may have seen in my other email from this afternoon, we would like to reschedule Ms. Graser’s 1/30/24 Zoom deposition to take place sometime after 2/9/24 so that we can attempt to receive the documentation we need from PNC and Discover prior to taking her deposition. Would any of the dates below work for Mr. Whaley/Mr. Koon? 2/13; 2/14 Afternoon; 2/15 Afternoon; 2/19; 2/20 Afternoon. Thank you, Jessica.” This outlined the proposed post-2/9/24 windows for rescheduling the Zoom deposition and the rationale of acquiring documents from PNC and Discover beforehand.

Jessica’s signature block followed, identifying her as a Paralegal for U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, with the firm’s contact details and a note stating: “Providing Workers Compensation defense throughout Kentucky and Indiana since 2002.” The email also included the firm’s website link.

In summary, the Estate of Keith Graser’s deposition of Nancy Graser was cancelled for 1/30/24, and multiple parties discussed rescheduling after 2/9/24 to obtain required documentation from PNC and Discover, with follow-up communications indicating the need to review any received documents before rescheduling and to confer with Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon before any second rescheduling.

Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser.

In late January 2024, communications circulated among the parties concerning the deposition of Nancy Graser in the Keith Graser matter. On January 18, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz, a paralegal with U’Sellis Mayer & Associates (email jwiedersatz@umakylaw.com) wrote to Sarena Tuttle at The Whaley Law Firm (sarena@whaleylawfirm.com) with the subject Deposition of Nancy Graser re Keith Graser. Jessica proposed rescheduling Ms. Graser’s 1/30/24 Zoom deposition to a date after February 9, 2024 to allow time to obtain documentation from PNC and Discover prior to the deposition. She asked which of the following dates would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon: February 13; February 14 (afternoon); February 15 (afternoon); February 19; or February 20 (afternoon). Jessica signed the message with her contact information and firm details, noting that her firm has been providing workers’ compensation defense in Kentucky and Indiana since 2002.

Later that same day, January 18, 2024, at 4:13 PM, Jessica’s message is echoed in an email thread as she reiterates the rescheduling request. The content again requests to shift the Zoom deposition of Ms. Graser to after February 9, 2024 so that documentation from PNC and Discover can be obtained beforehand, and asks whether any of the proposed dates would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon.

On January 19, 2024, at approximately 10:47 AM (the timestamp in the record shows as 10:47?AM), Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager for The Whaley Law Firm, responded. She stated that while she understood the desire to reschedule again, she would need to confer with Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon regarding any possible objections to a second rescheduling and would update Jessica as soon as possible. The message was signed with Sarena’s title and contact information, including her phone numbers and email address (please note new email address).

A follow-up message from Jessica on January 22, 2024, at 10:30 AM, again addressed to Sarena with copies to Greg Whaley and Bryce Koon, confirmed that her office had received the executed SDTs that morning. Sarena instructed to hold off on rescheduling for the time being, explaining that it could take time to obtain a proper response from the relevant companies and that their office would want to review any and all documents received before the deposition of Mrs. Graser. She invited Jessica to contact them directly with any questions and reiterated the importance of reviewing documents prior to deposition. Sarena’s message closed with her signature, including her title, firm, address (712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222), direct line (D: 502-357-9971) and office line (O: 502-583-4022 ext 104), and her new email address (Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com).

Finally, in the same thread on January 22, 2024 at 4:06 PM UTC, Jessica replied with a brief message thanking Sarena and attaching a notice canceling Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition. She signed off as Jessica, appending her contact details and reaffirming the cancellation of the deposition.

In summary, the Estate of Keith Graser’s deposition of Nancy Graser originally set for January 30, 2024, was canceled and notice of the cancellation was attached. The parties discussed multiple potential rescheduling dates after February 9, 2024 to allow time to obtain documentation from PNC and Discover, with ongoing consideration of objections to further rescheduling. The parties acknowledged receipt of executed subpoenas or related documents (SDTs) and agreed to review all received materials before proceeding with the deposition of Mrs. Graser, while remaining open to further contact to resolve questions or objections.

Client: Estate of Keith Graser

Recvd IME Addendum from Dr. Barefoot:
"I am in agreement with Dr. Wolens’ note that there were exposures both outside and inside the workplace during the COVID latency period.
However, it continues to be my opinion that it is more likely than not that his death was caused by COVID, secondary to his workplace exposure.
The depositions by his coworkers demonstrate that he could have been exposed to multiple individuals secondary to his workplace activity. It appears that during this timeframe, not all of the individuals at work that he could potentially be exposed to were masking or using social distancing as recommended at that time."
episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser.

An IME Addendum from Dr. Barefoot was received. In it, he states that he is in agreement with Dr. Wolens’ note that there were exposures both outside and inside the workplace during the COVID latency period. However, it continues to be his opinion that it is more likely than not that Keith Graser’s death was caused by COVID, secondary to his workplace exposure.

The Addendum also notes that the depositions by his coworkers demonstrate that he could have been exposed to multiple individuals secondary to his workplace activity. It appears that during this timeframe, not all of the individuals at work that he could potentially be exposed to were masking or using social distancing as recommended at that time.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
The Estate of Keith Graser, the client in the case labeled Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020, was involved in Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007. Beginning in January 2024, communications circulated between Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates and Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, with Sarena Tuttle of Whaley Law Firm copied on several messages. The primary issue was obtaining records from financial institutions (PNC and Discover Financial Services) via subpoenas duces tecum in order to support the case, with deposition dates being adjusted accordingly, and with a stated intent not to actually hold a deposition at that time.

On January 9, 2024, Lisa Chaffin informed Jessica Wiedersatz that Judge O’Bryan would sign the subpoenas. Later that day, Jessica repeated the message, asking to be apprised when the signing occurred. On January 9, 2024 at 3:01 PM and again at 4:17 PM, the correspondence centered on securing Judge O’Bryan’s signature for the subpoenas. On January 17, 2024, Lisa advised that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office the next day to sign, and Jessica followed up again for the status of the signing. The following day, January 18, 2024, Jessica explained that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and expressed concern that there would not be enough time to deliver the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by the deposition date of January 24, 2024, as indicated on the subpoenas. In light of this, Jessica attached updated subpoenas that carried a deposition date of February 9, 2024, and she noted that this would give more time to obtain Judge O’Bryan’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. She also indicated that she would be sending a subsequent email to reschedule Keith Graser’s deposition previously set for January 30, 2024, so that the documents from PNC and Discover could be reviewed before the deposition. Jessica told Lisa that Sarena was copied to keep her abreast of the communication, and she reaffirmed the intention to obtain the documents prior to depositions.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa sent a message stating that the subpoenas had been signed and attached. The tone throughout these exchanges included standard confidentiality notices typical of such communications, indicating that the messages contained confidential information and were intended for the exclusive use of the recipient.

By late January, the parties continued coordinating with the administrative office. Jessica acknowledged that Judge O’Bryan would sign the subpoenas and sought confirmation of the signing timeline. Lisa maintained that the judge would sign, and Jessica persisted in requesting updates. The parties repeatedly referenced the deposition dates and the need to obtain documents from PNC and Discover before proceeding with Keith Graser’s deposition.

As events progressed into February 2024, Jessica prepared and sent additional correspondence to Discover, attaching a letter, a subpoena duces tecum, and a deposition notice that were being sent to Discover Financial Services. She explained that the effort was strictly to obtain the requested information and that there was no plan to actually hold the deposition. Lisa Chaffin responded with the signed subpoena, attaching it to the email and inviting any further questions or concerns. Jessica, in turn, advised that the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed had been sent to Discover, but Discover had denied the request because the subpoena had not been sent to the correct address. She attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with the corrected Discover address and requested that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated document so that the records could again be sought from Discover. Jessica also noted that she had CC’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office to keep them informed of the communication.

In sum, these intertwined exchanges depict a concerted, ongoing effort from January through February 2024 to obtain records from Discover Financial Services (and, previously, PNC) through signed subpoenas duces tecum, with deposition dates being adjusted from an initial 1/24/2024 date to a new 2/9/2024 date, and with a plan to reschedule the 1/30/2024 deposition to ensure the requested documents were reviewed before deposition. Throughout, the parties conveyed the expectation that Judge O’Bryan would sign the subpoenas, and the communications included standard confidentiality notices as well as references to distributing copies to involved counsel.
episodes.author: Sarena Tuttle

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser. In the matter captioned Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction (2022-00007), communications were exchanged between the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, and the law firm handling Keith Graser’s estate regarding subpoenas duces tecum and deposition scheduling.

On January 9, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz, a paralegal at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, advised Lisa C. Chaffin, paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, that she had attached updated subpoenas after realizing she had not previously sent them. Lisa responded later that day that she would have Judge O’Bryan sign the subpoenas. The exchange included standard confidentiality notices in the email signatures.

Two days later, on January 9, 2024, Jessica followed up to confirm the status of the updated subpoenas she had sent and to ensure the judge would sign them. Lisa replied that there was no problem and that Judge O’Bryan would sign.

On January 17, 2024, Jessica checked in again to learn when Judge O’Bryan would sign the subpoenas. Lisa replied that the judge would be back in the office the next day to sign.

The next day, January 18, 2024, Jessica noted that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas and expressed concern that there would not be enough time to serve PNC and Discover by the deposition date of January 24, 2024, which had been provided on the subpoenas. She stated that she was attaching updated subpoenas with a deposition date of February 9, 2024, in hopes of allowing more time for Judge O’Bryan’s signatures and for sending the requests to PNC and Discover. Jessica also indicated she would send another email regarding rescheduling Keith Graser’s deposition set for January 30, 2024, so that documents from PNC and Discover could be obtained prior to taking the deposition, and she cc’d Sarena Tuttle to keep the Graser attorney’s office informed.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa sent a reply with the subject line indicating that the subpoenas had been signed, attaching them for Jessica’s review and inviting any questions or concerns.

Later, on February 6, 2024, Jessica reported that the subpoenas had been sent to Discover, but Discover denied the request because the request was not sent to the correct address. She attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with the correct Discover address and requested that Judge O’Bryan sign the document again so that they could pursue obtaining records from Discover. She again cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office.

That same day, February 6, 2024, at 3:50 PM (UTC), Lisa replied that the subpoena had been signed and attached as requested, inviting Jessica to contact her with any further questions or concerns.

All emails contained the standard confidentiality language noting that the communication is confidential and intended for the recipient, and that any disclosure or use by non-recipients may be unlawful. The communications also included the usual “CAUTION” notices about attachments in some messages. Jessica Wiedersatz’s email signature identified her as a Paralegal at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, with the firm’s Louisville contact information, and featured the firm’s motto: “Providing Workers Compensation defense throughout Kentucky and Indiana since 2002.” Lisa C. Chaffin’s signature identified her role as Paralegal to the Administrative Law Judge, with the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, and her contact information.

episodes.natural_language:
The case is Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020, with the client listed as the Estate of Keith Graser. The matter at hand is Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction, case number 2022-00007. In February 2024, communications occurred between counsel and the Kentucky Education and Labor Cabinet’s Department of Workers’ Claims regarding subpoenas and deposition notices directed to Discover Financial Services (and related records requests), as part of discovery in the case. The communications track both the preparation of subpoenas and attempts to schedule depositions, including changes to deposition dates and the need to obtain documents prior to taking deposition.

On January seventeenth, two thousand twenty-four, Lisa C. Chaffin, a paralegal with the Education & Labor Cabinet and a paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, informed Jessica Wiedersatz that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office the next day to sign subpoenas. Jessica followed up later that same day, asking for the status of the subpoenas.

On January eighteenth, Jessica reported that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas and expressed concern that there would not be enough time to deliver the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by January twenty-four, nineteen twenty-four, which was the deposition date stated on the subpoenas. To address this, she attached updated subpoenas that carried a deposition date of February ninth, twenty-twenty-four, explaining that this extension would give them more time to obtain the ALJ’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. She also noted that Sarena had been cc’d to stay abreast of the communication and that she would send another message regarding rescheduling Keith Graser’s deposition originally set for January thirtieth, twenty-twenty-four, since they wanted to have the documents from PNC and Discover prior to taking the deposition.

On January twenty-two, Lisa replied that the subpoenas had been signed and attached, inviting Jessica to contact her with any questions or concerns. A subsequent exchange on January seventeenth through January eighteenth included standard confidentiality notices in the emails from Lisa, reminding recipients that the communications contained confidential information intended only for the named recipients.

On January eighteenth, Jessica also noted that, because they had not yet received the signed subpoenas, there was insufficient time to meet the deposition timeline. She reiterated that the deposition date on the subpoenas had been set for January twenty-four, and that they had updated the subpoenas to reflect a February ninth deposition date to allow more time for ALJ signatures and for sending requests to PNC and Discover. She mentioned that Sarena would be cc’d and that she would send a separate email about rescheduling Ms. Graser’s deposition, which had been scheduled for January thirtieth, twenty-twenty-four, so that documents from PNC and Discover could be obtained first.

By February sixth, Jessica informed Lisa that they had sent the subpoena duces tecum, signed by Judge O’Bryan, to Discover Financial Services. She explained that Discover had denied the records request because it was not sent to the correct address and attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with a corrected Discover address, requesting that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated subpoena so they could again seek the records from Discover. She noted that she had cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office to keep them informed of the communication.

That same day, Lisa responded. She indicated that the signed subpoenas were attached and asked Jessica to let her know if there were any additional questions or concerns.

On February seventh, two thousand twenty-four, Sarena Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager for The Whaley Law Firm, replied, “Received, thank you,” and provided her contact information. She noted her new email address and included the Whaley Law Firm’s mailing address, along with direct and office phone numbers, and email.

Throughout this correspondence, the parties repeatedly referenced the subpoenas signed by Judge O’Bryan, the deposition notices directed to Discover, the need to obtain records from Discover and PNC, and the intent to schedule Ms. Graser’s deposition in a manner that allowed time to secure the requested documents before testimony. The communications also documented the ongoing collaboration among the legal teams, the ALJ’s office, and the client’s counsel as they navigated deposition dates and document production in connection with the Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction matter.

This note summarizes a sequence of email communications in the Estate-of-Keith-Graser matter, Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction (case number 2022-00007), in which the Estate of Keith Graser is represented by U’Sellis Mayer & Associates and the Whaley Law Firm is coordinating the discovery process and deposition scheduling. The exchange spans mid-January to early February 2024 and centers on subpoenas to obtain records from Discover Financial Services and PNC, as well as the scheduling of Ms. Graser’s deposition.

Beginning in mid-January 2024, Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, working as a paralegal to Administrative Law Judge Kimberly O’Bryan, indicated that Judge O’Bryan would be back in the office soon to sign subpoenas related to the case. On January 17, 2024, Lisa advised Jessica Wiedersatz that Judge O’Bryan would be available to sign the subpoenas the following day. Jessica followed up the same day, asking for the status of Judge O’Bryan’s signature on the subpoenas.

By January 18, 2024, Jessica expressed concern that signed subpoenas had not yet been returned, noting that there would not be enough time to serve the subpoenas on PNC and Discover before the deposition date of January 24, 2024. She attached updated subpoenas with a deposition date of February 9, 2024, hoping this would provide additional time for Judge O’Bryan’s signatures and for the requests to be sent to PNC and Discover. She indicated she would cc Sarena Tuttle to keep her informed and mentioned that she would issue another email regarding rescheduling Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition so that documents from PNC and Discover would be in hand prior to the deposition.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa responded with confirmation and attached the signed subpoenas, signaling that the signatories had been obtained and that the process could proceed.

As the process continued, Jessica reported on February 6, 2024 that they had sent the subpoena duces tecum, signed by Judge O’Bryan, to Discover. Discover denied the request because the notice had not been sent to the correct address, and Jessica attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with the correct address for Discover. She requested that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated subpoena so the records could be sought again from Discover. Jessica also cc’d Keith Graser’s attorneys to ensure they were aware of the communication.

Later on February 6, 2024, Lisa responded that the signed subpoena had been attached as requested. On February 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt of the subpoena.

By February 8, 2024, Jessica acknowledged that Discover had not yet produced the subpoenaed documents and reiterated that the deposition scheduling was contingent on obtaining those documents. She proposed several potential deposition dates for Ms. Graser, proposing that the deposition could start at 10:00 a.m. or 2:00 p.m., with flexibility on the start time. The dates she listed as open were February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only), and she asked for input on what would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon. She emphasized that the documents from Discover were desired before Ms. Graser’s deposition and noted that the proof time was set to end on March 8, 2024.

Throughout these exchanges, the communications included the usual formalities and contact details of the participants: Jessica Wiedersatz, a paralegal with U’Sellis Mayer & Associates; Sarena M. Tuttle, Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm; and Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, who coordinated the subpoenas with Administrative Law Judge O’Bryan. The thread confirms the parties’ shared objective of obtaining Discover’s records and scheduling Keith Graser’s deposition in a timely manner, balancing the need for documents with the court’s subpoena process and the scheduling realities of the involved attorneys.

episodes.natural_language:
In the case titled Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020, the client is the Estate of Keith Graser, involved in Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction (Case No. 2022-00007). Beginning in early 2024, the Whaley Law Firm’s litigation team, led by Jessica Wiedersatz of U’Sellis Mayer & Associates on the defense side, engaged in a series of communications to obtain subpoenas and to schedule the deposition of Ms. Graser, with the aim of obtaining documents from third parties before proceeding with deposition.

On January 6, 2024, Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, sent an email to Jessica with the signed subpoenas attached, indicating they were ready. By January 18, 2024, Jessica responded that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and expressed concern that there would not be enough time to send subpoenas to PNC and Discover by the deposition deadline of January 24, 2024. She noted that their proof time was set to end on March 8, 2024 and proposed moving Ms. Graser’s deposition to occur before that date to avoid calendar conflicts. She attached subpoenas with a deposition date of February 9, 2024 and stated they hoped to obtain ALJ O’Bryan’s signatures and to send the requests to PNC and Discover. She also mentioned cc’ing Sarena Tuttle to keep her informed and indicated she would send another email about rescheduling Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition so that documents from PNC and Discover could be reviewed prior to deposition.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa responded that the subpoenas had been signed and attached. In a subsequent exchange later that same day, Jessica wrote that they had sent the subpoena duces tecum that Judge O’Bryan had signed to Discover, but Discover denied the request because it was not sent to the correct address. She attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with a corrected Discover address and requested that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated document so they could attempt to obtain Discover’s records again. She also noted that she had cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office to keep them informed.

Earlier communications in the thread show that on February 6, 2024 Jessica again referenced subpoenas and related documents. She sent a message to Lisa indicating that they were emailing a letter, subpoena duces tecum, and deposition notice to Discover Financial Services to obtain the requested information, and she clarified that they did not plan to actually hold the deposition at that time. Lisa responded with confirmation and asked Jessica to advise if there were further questions or concerns. In response, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt of that communication on February 7, 2024.

By February 7 and February 8, 2024, the scheduling discussions intensified. Sarena replied “Received, thank you,” and in a separate message she told Jessica that they could schedule Ms. Graser’s deposition on either February 28 or February 29. In Jessica’s reply, she reiterated the ongoing issue of awaiting subpoenaed documents from Discover, noting that the subpoena’s due date was February 26, 2024. She explained that they wanted Discover’s documents before Ms. Graser’s deposition and that, given their proof time ending March 8, 2024, they preferred scheduling before that deadline to avoid calendar pressures. She listed several potential start times and dates—10:00 AM or 2:00 PM—and asked which would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon, offering flexibility on the start time. The proposed dates included February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (with March 4 being set for the morning only).

Finally, on February 12, 2024, Sarena replied to Jessica that they could do the deposition on February 28 or February 29, reaffirming the possible dates and indicating continued coordination. Throughout these exchanges, the parties repeatedly referenced the subpoenas, the deposition notices, and the goal of obtaining Discover’s and PNC’s documents prior to Ms. Graser’s deposition, while balancing calendar constraints and the procedural deadlines set by the court and ALJ O’Bryan.

The client listed for the file is the Estate of Keith Graser.

On January 17, 2024, Lisa C. Earlier, on January 22, 2024, Lisa confirmed via email that the signed subpoenas were attached and available for use. The thread shows the ongoing coordination among Jessica, Sarena, and the Whaley firm’s clients in relation to the subpoenas and the deposition timeline.

Subsequently, on February 6, 2024, Jessica informed Lisa that Discover had denied the subpoena request because it had been sent to the incorrect address, and she noted that the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed was being resent with an updated Discover address. She stated that they would ask Judge O’Bryan to sign the updated subpoena so they could again attempt to obtain records from Discover and cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office to keep them informed. In the same message, Jessica attached the updated subpoena duces tecum and reiterated the purpose of obtaining the requested information rather than holding the deposition at that time.

That same day, February 6, Jessica attached the letter, subpoena duces tecum, and deposition notice to Discover Financial Services and explained that the earlier request had been denied due to the incorrect address, and requested that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated subpoena so records could be sought again. There is also a note indicating the contents were intended for the recipient and a confidentiality disclaimer.

On February 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied, acknowledging receipt of Jessica’s communications with thanks.

On February 8, 2024, Jessica reiterated that they were awaiting subpoenaed documents from Discover and reminded that the subpoena’s due date was February 26, 2024. She explained the need to obtain Discover’s documents before taking Ms. Graser’s deposition and, given that the proof time would end on March 8, 2024, proposed scheduling Ms. Graser’s deposition before that date. She listed several open dates for deposition: February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only) and indicated that a start time of 10:00 a.m. or 2:00 p.m. would work, though they were flexible.

On February 12, 2024, Sarena responded that they could do deposition on February 28 or February 29, confirming availability on those dates.

On February 13, 2024, Jessica replied, proposing February 29, 2024, provided it was still available, and asked whether 10:00 a.m. would work. She stated, “Let’s go with 2/29, please, if still available. How does 10AM sound?”

In summary, the file involves the Estate of Keith Graser pursuing discovery through subpoenas to Discover Financial Services and other entities, with the deposition of Ms. Graser contemplated to occur after the discovery materials were obtained, and a scheduling process that spanned January to February 2024, including multiple proposed dates (2/28, 2/29, 3/1, 3/4 mornings) and a preferred start time of 10:00 a.m. or 2:00 p.m., ultimately leaning toward February 29, 2024 at 10:00 a.m., contingent on availability and the resolution of Discover’s subpoena issues. The emails reflect coordination among Jessica Wiedersatz (paralegal with U’Sellis Mayer & Associates), Sarena M. Tuttle (Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm), and Lisa C. Chaffin (Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims), with references to Judge O’Bryan and the need to obtain signed subpoenas and associated records in order to prepare for deposition.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser. Re: Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007. On February 14, 2024, at 9:26:32 AM Eastern Time, Sarena M. Tuttle, the litigation paralegal and workers’ compensation case manager at The Whaley Law Firm, sent an email to Jessica Wiedersatz regarding the Keith Graser matter. In that message, she stated that a 10:00 AM deposition would be fine and that she would note it on their calendar. Her signature block included her name, title, and contact details: The Whaley Law Firm, 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222; direct dial 502-357-9971; office 502-583-4022 ext. 104; email Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com, with a note indicating a new email address.

Earlier correspondence shows a back-and-forth beginning in early February 2024. On February 8, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz wrote that they were still awaiting subpoenaed documents from Discover Financial Services, with the subpoena due date set for February 26, 2024. She noted that they wanted to have Discover’s documents prior to taking Ms. Graser’s deposition and, given their proof time ending March 8, 2024, the deposition should occur before then to avoid calendar conflicts if Discover’s documents arrived late. She listed open dates with start times of 10:00 AM or 2:00 PM as workable, specifically noting February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only) as available, and asked for confirmation of what would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon.

On February 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied, acknowledging receipt and thanking Jessica. Her signature again listed The Whaley Law Firm’s contact information and her title as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, with the new email address noted. 

The chain also records earlier steps in the subpoena process. On February 6, 2024 at 11:42 AM, Jessica advised that she had attached a copy of the letter, subpoena duces tecum, and deposition notice that they were sending to Discover Financial Services, emphasizing that the deposition was not intended to occur at that time. Also on February 6, 2024 at 10:51 AM, Lisa C. Chaffin (Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims) wrote that the signed subpoena was attached as requested and invited questions or concerns. Earlier on February 6, 2024 at 10:31 AM, Jessica explained that they had sent the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed to Discover, but Discover denied the request because it was not sent to the correct address; an updated subpoena with a corrected address for Discover was attached, and they asked that Judge O’Bryan sign the updated subpoena so they could again attempt to obtain records from Discover. Jessica also noted that Graser’s attorneys had been cc’d to keep them informed.

The record then moves back to January. On January 22, 2024 at 8:34 AM, Lisa Chaffin reported that the subpoenas were signed and attached, inviting any questions or concerns. On January 18, 2024 at 4:07 PM, Jessica Wiedersatz responded to Lisa, expressing concern that they had not yet received the signed subpoenas back and that there might not be enough time to deliver the subpoenas to PNC and Discover by January 24, 2024, which was the deposition date provided. The message included cautionary notes about PDF attachments and contained the standard confidentiality notice from the Kentucky Education & Labor Cabinet communications. The email thread then appears to include a duplicated or truncated continuation of the January 18 message, ending with an incomplete sentence: “Hi, Lisa – As you we have not yet received the signed subpoenas back, I’m concerned that there would not be enough time for us to get the subpoenas to PNC and Discover in time to respond by 1/.”

In sum, the case notes document a coordinated effort among the Estate of Keith Graser’s counsel and opposing counsel to coordinate Ms. Graser’s deposition scheduling while pursuing subpoenas for documents from Discover Financial Services (and PNC), with discovery deadlines and deposition timing under discussion from mid-January through mid-February 2024. The latest scheduling note on February 14, 2024 confirms a 10:00 AM deposition time for February 29, contingent on availability.

episodes.natural_language:
In the Estate of Keith Graser, case number Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020, which concerns Keith Graser and his estate as the client, the matter Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007 unfolded through a series of discovery communications in February 2024. The communications involved Jessica Wiedersatz of Umaky Law Firm (UMAKY LAW) and Sarena M. Tuttle, a litigation paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, along with Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet and others, in the process of issuing subpoenas and scheduling depositions related to Discover Financial Services and PNC, and to prepare for Ms. Graser’s deposition.

The exchange began with Jessica on January 18, 2024, explaining that signed subpoenas had not yet been returned and voicing concern that there would not be enough time to serve subpoenas on PNC and Discover by the deposition date of January 24, 2024. She indicated a deposition date for Ms. Graser had been provided on the subpoenas, and she proposed rescheduling to February 9, 2024, to allow time for signatures and for the subpoenas to be sent to PNC and Discover. She also noted plans to reschedule Ms. Graser’s January 30, 2024 deposition and provided updated subpoenas with a deposition date of February 9, 2024, in the hope of obtaining the ALJ’s signatures and time to send the requests.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa C. Chaffin replied with attached, signed subpoenas and invited any questions or concerns. The following days reflected ongoing coordination: on February 6, 2024, Jessica reported that they had sent a subpoena duces tecum signed by Judge O’Bryan to Discover, but Discover denied the request because it had been sent to the wrong address. She attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with the correct Discover address and requested that Judge O’Bryan sign it so that they could again attempt to obtain records from Discover. In the same message, Jessica cc’d Keith Graser’s attorneys to keep them informed.

That same day, February 6, 2024, Lisa Chaffin replied with “Attached is the signed subpoena as requested,” confirming she had provided the signed document. Jessica acknowledged receipt of that confirmation. The following day, February 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle replied with a brief note: “Received, thank you.” 

By February 8, 2024, Jessica noted that they were still awaiting documents from Discover and reminded that the subpoena’s due date was February 26, 2024. She explained the plan to conduct Ms. Graser’s deposition before that date, because if they waited for Discover’s documents, the attorneys’ calendars might become too full to accommodate the deposition. She listed potential deposition dates that were open: February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only), with a 10:00 AM or 2:00 PM start time being acceptable but flexible.

On February 12, 2024, Sarena stated that they could do either February 28 or February 29 for the deposition. Jessica then proposed February 29, 2024, at 10:00 AM, asking if that time worked for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon. On February 14, 2024, Sarena replied that 10:00 AM would be fine and she would note it on their calendar, also providing her updated contact details and noting a new email address for herself.

Later on February 14, 2024, Jessica confirmed that she had attached a copy of the deposition notice for the file. In the same set of messages, Sarena’s contact details were updated to reflect a new email address, and Jessica signaled that the deposition notice would accompany the file.

Throughout these exchanges, the parties discussed the interplay between the subpoenas, the request for documents from Discover and PNC, and the scheduling of Keith Graser’s deposition, with a primary objective of securing the documents prior to Ms. Graser’s deposition and before the discovery-related deadlines. The deposition was ultimately scheduled for February 29, 2024, at 10:00 AM, subject to availability and Discover’s document production, and Jessica’s and Sarena’s communications culminated with the attached notice for the file.

episodes.natural_language:
Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020 concerns the client, the Estate of Keith Graser, in the matter captioned Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction, 2022-00007. The communications excerpted here document the efforts of counsel to schedule Keith Graser’s deposition and to obtain discovery from Discover Financial Services in connection with the case. The Whaley Law Firm represents the estate, and Jessica Wiedersatz of UMAKYLaw (UMAKY?) represents the opposing side in these exchanges.

The correspondence begins with a January 18, 2024 message from Jessica Wiedersatz to Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, cc’ing Sarena Tuttle of The Whaley Law Firm. Jessica explains that they had sent the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed to Discover, but Discover denied the request because it had not been sent to the correct address. She asks that Judge O’Bryan sign an updated subpoena duces tecum with the corrected Discover address so they may again attempt to obtain Discover’s records. She cc’d Keith Graser’s attorneys on the email.

On January 22, 2024, Lisa Chaffin replied with attached subpoenas, noting that they were signed subpoenas. Lisa’s email includes her contact details as a paralegal to the Administrative Law Judge and references the confidential nature of the communication.

On February 6, 2024, Jessica Wiedersatz again corresponded with Lisa Chaffin, stating that Discover had been sent the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed, but Discover denied the request because the address was incorrect. She mentions that an updated subpoena duces tecum with the correct Discover address is attached and requests that Judge O’Bryan sign it so they may once again attempt to obtain records from Discover. Jessica cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office. Lisa responded with the attached signed subpoena, and Jessica included the standard confidentiality notices and disclaimers typical to such correspondence, including a caution about PDF attachments potentially containing links and a formal confidentiality disclaimer.

On February 7, 2024, Sarena Tuttle acknowledged receipt of Lisa’s signed subpoena and thanked her.

On February 8, 2024, Jessica provided additional context: they were awaiting subpoenaed documents from Discover, with a subpoena due date of February 26, 2024. They wanted to schedule Ms. Graser’s deposition before March 8, 2024, to avoid calendar conflicts should Discover’s documents be received later. Jessica listed several potential deposition dates—February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only)—and indicated that a 10:00 AM or 2:00 PM start time would work, with flexibility. She requested to know what would work for Mr. Whaley (presumably Greg Whaley) and Mr. Koon.

On February 12, 2024, Sarena responded that they could do either February 28 or February 29, and she noted her calendar details and provided the firm’s contact information, including her new email address.

On February 13, 2024, Jessica suggested proceeding with February 29, if still available, and proposed a start time of 10:00 AM.

On February 14, 2024, Sarena confirmed that 10:00 AM would be fine and that she would note it on the calendar. Jessica replied that the deposition notice had been attached for Sarena’s file and thanked her again. The email thread includes the standard Whaley Law Firm signature block for Sarena Tuttle, including her title as Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, her firm’s address at 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222, and her contact details, including her newly noted email address. Jessica’s reply also includes her firm’s signature block, with the UMAKYLaw contact information and a disclaimer regarding confidentiality and the risks associated with PDF attachments.

In summary, this series of communications documents the coordinated effort to obtain discovery from Discover Financial Services and to schedule Keith Graser’s deposition in the Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction matter (2022-00007). The parties settled on a deposition date of February 29, 2024, at 10:00 AM, with the deposition notice attached to the file, and the discovery process pending the production of documents from Discover, which was anticipated by the March 8, 2024 proof time. The involved parties’ attorneys and staff include Sarena M. Tuttle (Whaley Law Firm), Jessica Wiedersatz (UMAKYLaw), and Lisa C. Chaffin (Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims), with the relevant client being the Estate of Keith Graser.

The email included Jessica’s standard signature with U’Sellis Mayer & Associates’ contact information and website, and a note that the firm provides Workers’ Compensation defense throughout Kentucky and Indiana since 2002.

- On February 6, 2024, Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet, Department of Workers’ Claims, replied with the signed subpoenas attached, indicating that she was the Paralegal to Kimberly O’Bryan, Administrative Law Judge, and providing her contact details (lisa.chaffin@ky.gov; 502/782-3919). The message included a confidentiality disclaimer typical of the correspondence from the Department of Workers’ Claims.

- On January 22, 2024, at 8:34 AM, Lisa C. Chaffin replied to Jessica: “Attached are the signed subpoenas. Please let me know if you have any questions or additional concerns.” This message carried the same confidentiality disclaimer.

- On January 18, 2024, at 4:07 PM, Jessica sent Lisa a message with the subject “RE: Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007.” The email carried a caution about PDF attachments potentially containing links to malicious sites and stated: “Hi, Lisa – As you we have not yet received the signed subpoenas back, I’m concerned that there would not be enough time for us to get the subpoenas to PNC and Discover in time to respond by 1/24/24, which was the deposition date provided on” (the sentence trails off in the record). A subsequent line repeats: “Hi, Lisa – We sent the subpoena duces tecum Judge O’Bryan had signed to Discover. Unfortunately, our request for records was denied by Discover as the request was not sent to the correct address. Please find attached an updated subpoena duces tecum with an updated address for Discover. We would ask that Judge O’Bryan please sign same so that we may again attempt to obtain records from Discover.” Jessica also noted that she had cc’d Mr. Graser’s attorney’s office. The email signature included Jessica’s position at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates and contact information.

- Earlier in the chain, on January 22, 2024 and January 18, 2024, messages from Lisa Chaffin and Jessica included standard confidentiality notices and sign-offs typical of communications from the Department of Workers’ Claims and the U’Sellis Mayer & Associates firm.

Additional context from the record includes the personnel and contact details involved:

- Jessica Wiedersatz is identified as a Paralegal at U’Sellis Mayer & Associates, located at 100 Mallard Creek Road, Suite 110, Louisville, KY 40207. Her phone and fax numbers are listed as part of her signature, and the firm’s website is www.umakylaw.com. Her email is jwiedersatz@umakylaw.com.

- Sarena M. Tuttle is identified as a Litigation Paralegal & Workers’ Compensation Case Manager at The Whaley Law Firm, with the office address 712 Lyndon Lane, Louisville, KY 40222. Her direct line is (502) 357-9971, her main line is (502) 583-4022 ext 104, and her email is Sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com. A note in her signature indicates a “PLEASE NOTE NEW EMAIL ADDRESS.”

- The deposition notice and related correspondence refer to a deposition date previously contemplated around late February 2024, with initial possibilities including 2/28, 2/29, 3/1, and 3/4 (morning only), and a plan to schedule Ms. Graser’s deposition before the end of the proof time on 3/8/24.

- The deposition topic noted in the Zoom notice is “Depo/Nancy Graser re Keith Graser,” with the scheduled time of 10:00 AM on February 29, 2024 (Eastern Time). The Zoom meeting is identified by the Meeting ID 845 1311 7701, and the Join URL is https://us06web.zoom.us/j/84513117701.

In summary, during January and February 2024, the parties worked to obtain signed subpoenas for Discover and PNC, address delivery issues with Discover, and finalize the deposition schedule for Ms. Graser’s deposition in the Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction action. A corrected Zoom notice was issued on February 14, 2024 for a deposition set for February 29, 2024 at 10:00 AM Eastern, with the correct Zoom link and Meeting ID provided, following prior scheduling discussions that had considered 2/28, 2/29, 3/1, and 3/4 as possibilities. The email chain preserves the involved participants, their roles, contact details, and the confidentiality notices that accompany several communications.

episodes.natural_language:
Case: Estate-of-Keith-Graser-WC-12-07-2020. Client: Estate of Keith Graser. Re: Keith Graser v. Coupe Construction 2022-00007. From Jessica Wiedersatz (jwiedersatz@umakylaw.com) to Sarena Tuttle (sarena@WhaleyLawFirm.com), dated February 23, 2024 at 15:39:52 UTC, with the subject noting the Keith Graser matter.

Jessica explains that a subpoena duces tecum was sent to Discover Financial Services to obtain account information. The subpoena had a due date of February 26, 2024. This morning, Discover advised that they cannot meet the 2/26/24 deadline and expect to respond by March 28, 2024. Jessica notes she is hopeful the records will be received before the end of March, but she also points out that the parties’ BRC is scheduled for March 27, 2024. She asks if Ms. Graser’s deposition could be pushed back to about a week before the BRC and asks Sarena to check whether the following dates—March 18, 19, 20, or 21—might work, inviting Sarena to confirm a start time.

This message follows an earlier thread. On February 14, 2024, Jessica told Sarena that she had made a mistake and had to change the Zoom link for Ms. Graser’s upcoming deposition. She asks Sarena to discard the notice she had sent earlier that day and use an attached notice with the correct Zoom link, which she provides again below. The correct Zoom details specify a session titled “Depo/Nancy Graser re Keith Graser,” scheduled for February 29, 2024 at 10:00 AM Eastern Time, hosted via Zoom. The join link is https://us06web.zoom.us/j/84513117701 with Meeting ID 845 1311 7701.

Earlier in the day on February 14, Jessica had sent a copy of the deposition notice for Sarena’s file. Sarena responded the same day, confirming that 10:00 AM would be fine and that she would note it on the calendar.

The chain leading up to these arrangements began on February 12, 2024, when Sarena replied that they could do the deposition on either February 28 or February 29. A prior exchange on February 13 showed Jessica proposing February 29, 2024, at 10:00 AM if that date remained available. On February 7, 2024, Sarena had acknowledged receipt of the scheduling information in a brief reply. Prior to that, on February 6, 2024, Jessica had written that she and the team were sending out a subpoena duces tecum to Discover, noting that Discover had previously denied the request because it had not been sent to the correct address; she attached an updated subpoena with the corrected address and requested Judge O’Bryan’s signature so the records request could be reattempted, cc’ing Mr. Graser’s attorneys to keep them informed. Lisa C. Chaffin of the Education & Labor Cabinet had earlier provided the signed subpoenas on January 22, 2024, confirming that the subpoenas were attached and ready for use.

Jessica had also emphasized that Discover’s production was not expected to occur before the deposition; she reminded that the deposition planning was being pursued in the context of the ongoing subpoena efforts. She noted that the parties’ proof time was set to end on March 8, 2024, and they preferred to schedule Ms. Graser’s deposition before that deadline if possible. The proposed dates in that earlier window were February 28, February 29, March 1, and March 4 (morning only), with start times of either 10:00 AM or 2:00 PM, depending on what would work for Mr. Whaley and Mr. Koon.

The email chain also includes standard confidentiality notices and references to the parties involved in The Whaley Law Firm, including Sarena M. Tuttle, a Litigation Paralegal and Workers’ Compensation Case Manager, and the firm’s Louisville, Kentucky contact details. The correspondence from Lisa C. Chaffin and Lisa’s earlier communications confirm a procedural path for obtaining the subpoenaed records and coordinating the deposition schedule alongside the regulatory process.

In summary, the estate’s counsel sought Discover records via subpoena with a February 26 deadline, which Discover could not meet; a response was anticipated by March 28. Given the March 27 BRC date, the team proposed rescheduling Keith Graser’s deposition to a date about a week before the BRC, with available slots from March 18 through March 21, 2024. Concurrently, they managed the deposition logistics for February 29, 2024 at 10:00 AM Eastern, including correcting a Zoom link and ensuring all notice materials were properly circulated and attached.
